books.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I

chapters.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:1
verses.text: Against the Pelagians:  Book I.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:2
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:3
verses.text: Atticus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:4
verses.text: I hear, Critobulus, that you have written that man can be without sin, if he chooses; and that the commandments of God are easy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:5
verses.text: Tell me, is it true?  Critobulus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:6
verses.text: It is true, Atticus; but our rivals do not take the words in the sense I attached to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:8
verses.text: Are they then so ambiguous as to give rise to a difference as to their meaning? I do not ask for an answer to two questions at once.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:9
verses.text: You laid down two propositions; the one, that man can be without sin, if he chooses: the other, that God's commandments are easy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:10
verses.text: Although, therefore, they were uttered together, let them be discussed separately, so that, while our faith appears to be one, no strife may arise through our misunderstanding each other.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:11
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:12
verses.text: I said, Atticus, that man can be without sin, if he chooses; not, as some maliciously make us say, without the grace of God (the very thought is impiety), but simply that he can, if he chooses; the aid of the grace of God being presupposed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:13
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:14
verses.text: Is God, then, the author of your evil works?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:15
verses.text: By no means.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:16
verses.text: But if there is any good in me, it is brought to perfection through His impulse and assistance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:17
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:18
verses.text: My question does not refer to natural constitution, but to action.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:19
verses.text: For who doubts that God is the Creator of all things? I wish you would tell me this: the good you do, is it your's or God's?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:20
verses.text: It is mine and God's: I work and He assists.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:21
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:22
verses.text: How is it then that everybody thinks you do away with the grace of God, and maintain that all our actions proceed from our own will?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:23
verses.text: I am surprised, Atticus, at your asking me for the why and wherefore of other people's mistakes, and wanting to know what I did not write, when what I did write is perfectly clear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:24
verses.text: I said that man can be without sin, if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:25
verses.text: Did I add, without the grace of God?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:26
verses.text: No; but the fact that you added nothing implies your denial of the need of grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:27
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:28
verses.text: Nay, rather, the fact that I have not denied grace should be regarded as tantamount to an assertion of it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:29
verses.text: It is unjust to suppose we deny whatever we do not assert.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:30
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:31
verses.text: You admit then that man can be sinless, if he chooses, but with the grace of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:32
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:33
verses.text: I not only admit it, but freely proclaim it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:34
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:35
verses.text: So then he who does away with the grace of God is in error.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:36
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:37
verses.text: Just so.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:38
verses.text: Or rather, he ought to be thought impious, seeing that all things are governed by the pleasure of God, and that we owe our existence and the faculty of individual choice and desire to the goodness of God, the Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:39
verses.text: For that we have free will, and according to our own choice incline to good or evil, is part of His grace who made us what we are, in His own image and likeness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:40
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:41
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:42
verses.text: No one doubts, Critobulus, that all things depend on the judgment of Him Who is Creator of all, and that whatever we have ought to be attributed to His goodness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:43
verses.text: But I should like to know respecting this faculty, which you attribute to the grace of God, whether you reckon it as part of the gift bestowed in our creation, or suppose it energetic in our separate actions, so that we avail ourselves of its assistance continually; or is it the case that, having been once for all created and endowed with free will, we do what we choose by our own choice or strength? For I know that very many of your party refer all things to the grace of God in such a sense that they understand the power of the will to be a gift not of a particular, but of a general character, that is to say, one which is bestowed not at each separate moment, but once for all at creation.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:44
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:45
verses.text: It is not as you affirm; but I maintain both positions, that it is by the grace of God we were created such as we are, and also that in our several actions we are supported by His aid.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:46
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:47
verses.text: We are agreed, then, that in good works, besides our own power of choice, we lean on the help of God; in evil works we are prompted by the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:48
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:49
verses.text: Quite so; there is no difference of opinion on that point.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:50
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:51
verses.text: They are wrong, then, who strip us of the help of God in our separate actions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:52
verses.text: The Psalmist sings:"Except the Lord build the house, they labour in vain who build it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:53
verses.text: Except the Lord keep the city, the watchman waketh but in vain;" and there are similar passages.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:54
verses.text: But these men endeavour by perverse, or rather ridiculous interpretations, to twist his words to a different meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:55
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:56
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:57
verses.text: Am I bound to contradict others when you have my own answer?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:58
verses.text: Your answer to what effect? That they are right, or wrong?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:59
verses.text: What necessity compels me to set my opinion against other men's?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:60
verses.text: You are bound by the rules of discussion, and by respect for truth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:61
verses.text: Do you not know that every assertion either affirms, or denies, and that what is affirmed or denied ought to be reckoned among good or bad things? You must, therefore, admit, and no thanks to you, that the statement to which my question relates is either a good thing or a bad.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:62
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:63
verses.text: If in particular actions we must have the help of God, does it follow that we are unable to make a pen,or mend it when it is made? Can we not fashion the letters, be silent or speak, sit, stand, walk or run, eat or fast, weep or laugh, and so on, without God's assistance?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:64
verses.text: From my point of view it is clearly impossible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:65
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:66
verses.text: How then have we free will, and how can we guard the grace of God towards us, if we cannot do even these things without God?  4.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:67
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:68
verses.text: The bestowal of the grace of free will is not such as to do away with the support of God in particular actions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:69
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:70
verses.text: The help of God is not made of no account; inasmuch as creatures are preserved through the grace of free will once for all given to them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:71
verses.text: For if without God, and except He assist me in every action, I can do nothing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:72
verses.text: He can neither with justice crown me for my good deeds, nor punish me for my evil ones, but in each case He will either receive His own or will condemn the assistants He gave.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:73
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:74
verses.text: Tell me, then, plainly, why you do away with the grace of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:75
verses.text: For whatever you destroy in the parts you must of necessity deny in the whole.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:76
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:77
verses.text: I do not deny grace when I assert that I was so created by God, that by the grace of God it was put within the power of my choice either to do a thing or not to do it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:78
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:79
verses.text: So God falls asleep over our good actions, when once the faculty of free will has been given; and we need not pray to Him to assist us in our separate actions, since it depends upon our own choice and will either to do a thing if we choose, or not to do it if we do not choose.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:80
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:81
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:82
verses.text: As in the case of other creatures, the conditions of elicit creation are observed; so, when once the power of free will was granted, everything was left to our own choice.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:83
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:84
verses.text: It follows, as I said, that I ought not to beg the assistance of God in the details of conduct, because I consider it was given once for all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:85
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:86
verses.text: If He co-operates with me in everything the result is no longer mine, but His Who assists, or rather works in and with me; and all the more because I can do nothing without Him.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:87
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:88
verses.text: Have you not read, pray, "that it is not of him that willeth, nor of him that runneth, but of God that showeth mercy!" From this we understand that to will and to run is ours, but the carrying into effect our willing and running pertains to the mercy of God, and is so effected that on the one hand in willing and running free will is preserved; and on the other, in consummating our willing and running, everything is left to the power of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:89
verses.text: Of course, I ought now to adduce the frequent testimony of Scripture to show that in the details of conduct the saints intreat the help of God, and in their several actions desire to have Him for their helper and protector.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:90
verses.text: Read through the Psalter, and all the utterances of the saints, and you will find their actions never unaccompanied by prayer to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:91
verses.text: And this is a clear proof that you either deny the grace which you banish from the parts of life; or if you concede its presence in the parts, a concession plainly much against your will, you must have come over to the views of us who preserve free will for man, but so limit it that we do not deny the assistance of God in each action.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:92
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:93
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:94
verses.text: That is a sophistical conclusion and a mere display of logical skill.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:95
verses.text: No one can strip me of the power of free will; otherwise, if God were really my helper in what I do, the reward would not be due to me, but to Him who wrought in me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:96
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:97
verses.text: Make the most of your free will; arm your tongue against God, and therein prove yourself free, if you will, to blaspheme.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:98
verses.text: But to go a step farther, there is no doubt as to your sentiments, and the delusions of your profession have become as clear as day.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:99
verses.text: Now, let us turn back to the starting-point of our discussion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:100
verses.text: You said just now that, granted God's assistance, man may be sinless if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:101
verses.text: Tell me, please, for how long? For ever, or only for a short time?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:102
verses.text: Your question is unnecessary.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:103
verses.text: If I say for a short time, for ever will none the less be implied.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:104
verses.text: For whatever you allow for a short time, you will admit may last for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:105
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:106
verses.text: I do not quite understand your meaning.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:107
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:108
verses.text: Are you so senseless that you do not recognize plain facts?  7.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:109
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:110
verses.text: I am not ashamed of my ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:111
verses.text: And both sides ought to be well agreed on a definition of the subject of dispute.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:112
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:113
verses.text: I maintain this: he who can keep himself from sin one day, may do so another day: if he can on two, he may on three; if on three, on thirty: and so on for three hundred, or three thousand, or as long as ever he chooses to do so.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:114
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:115
verses.text: Say then at once that a man may be without sin for ever, if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:116
verses.text: Can we do anything we like?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:117
verses.text: Certainly not, for I cannot do all I should like; but all I say is this, that a man can be without sin, if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:118
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:119
verses.text: Be so good as to tell me this: do you think I am a man or a beast?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:120
verses.text: If I had any doubt as to whether you were a man, or a beast, I should confess myself to be the latter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:121
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:122
verses.text: If then, as you say, I am a man, how is it that when I wish and earnestly desire not to sin, I do transgress?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:123
verses.text: Because your choice is imperfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:124
verses.text: If you really wished not to sin, you really would not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:125
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:126
verses.text: Well then, you who accuse me of not having a real desire, are you free from sin because you have a real desire?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:127
verses.text: As though I were talking of myself whom I admit to be a sinner, and not of the few exceptional ones, if any, who have resolved not to sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:128
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:129
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:130
verses.text: Still, I who question, and you who answer, both consider ourselves sinners.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:131
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:132
verses.text: But we are capable of not being so, if we please.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:133
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:134
verses.text: I said I did not wish to sin, and no doubt your feeling is the same.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:135
verses.text: How is it then that what we both wish we can neither do?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:136
verses.text: Because we do not wish perfectly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:137
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:138
verses.text: Show me any of our ancestors who had a perfect will and the power in perfection.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:139
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:140
verses.text: That is not easy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:141
verses.text: And when I say that a man may be without sin if he chooses, I do not contend that there ever have been such; I only maintain the abstract possibility—if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:142
verses.text: For possibility of being is one thing, and is expressed in Greek by τῇ δυνάμει (possibility); being is another, the equivalent for which is τῇ ἐνεργεί& 139· (actuality).

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:143
verses.text: I can be a physician; but meanwhile I am not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:144
verses.text: I can be an artisan; but I have not yet learnt a trade.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:145
verses.text: So, whatever I am able to be, though I am not that yet, I shall be if I choose.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:146
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:147
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:148
verses.text: Art is one thing, that which isabove art is another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:149
verses.text: Medical skill, craftsmanship, and so on, are found in many persons; but to be always without sin is a characteristic of the Divine power only.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:150
verses.text: Therefore, either give me an instance of those who were for ever without sin; or, if you cannot find one, confess your impotence, lay aside bombast, and do not mock the ears of fools with this being and possibility of being of yours.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:151
verses.text: For who will grant that a man can do what no man was ever able to do? You have not learnt even the rudiments of logic.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:152
verses.text: For if a man is able, he is no longer unable.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:153
verses.text: Either grant that some one was able to do what you maintain was possible to be done; or if no one has had this power, you must, though against your will, be held to this position, that no one is able to effect what yet you profess to be possible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:154
verses.text: That was the point at issue between the powerful logicians,Diodorus andChrysippus, in their discussion of possibility.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:155
verses.text: Diodorus says that alone can possibly happen which is either true or will be true.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:156
verses.text: And whatever will be, that, he says, must of necessity happen.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:157
verses.text: But whatever will not be, that cannot possibly happen.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:158
verses.text: Chrysippus, however, says that things which will not be might happen; for instance, this pearl might be broken, even though it never will.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:159
verses.text: They, therefore, who say that a man can be without sin if he chooses, will not be able to prove the truth of the assertion, unless they show that it will come to pass.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:160
verses.text: But whereas the whole future is uncertain, and especially such things as have never occurred, it is clear that they say something will be which will not be.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:161
verses.text: And Ecclesiastes supports this decision: "All that shall be, has already been in former ages".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:162
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:163
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:164
verses.text: Pray answer this question: has God given possible or impossible commands?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:165
verses.text: I see your drift.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:166
verses.text: But I must discuss it later on, that we may not, by confusing different questions, leave our audience in a fog.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:167
verses.text: I admit that God has given possible commands, for otherwise He would Himself be the author of injustice, were He to demand the doing of what cannot possibly be done.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:168
verses.text: Reserving this until later, finish your argument that a man can be without sin, if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:169
verses.text: You will either give instances of such ability, or, if no one has had the power, you will clearly confess that a man cannot avoid sin always.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:170
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:171
verses.text: Since you press me to give what I am not bound to give, consider what our Lord says,"That it is easier for a camel to go through a needle's eye, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:172
verses.text: And yet he said a thing might possibly happen, which never has happened.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:173
verses.text: For no camel has ever gone through a needle's eye.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:174
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:175
verses.text: I am surprised at a prudent man submitting evidence which goes against himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:176
verses.text: For the passage in question does not speak of a possibility, but one impossibility is compared with another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:177
verses.text: As a camel cannot go through a needle's eye, so neither will a rich man enter the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:178
verses.text: Or, if you should be able to show that a rich man does enter the kingdom of heaven, it follows, also, that a camel goes through a needle's eye.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:179
verses.text: You must not instance Abraham and other rich men, about whom we read in the Old Testament, who, although they were rich, entered the kingdom of heaven; for, by spending their riches on good works, they ceased to be rich; nay, rather, inasmuch as they were rich, not for themselves, but for others, they ought to be called God's stewards rather than rich men.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:180
verses.text: But we must seek evangelical perfection, according to which there is the command, "If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell all that thou hast, and give to the poor, and come, follow Me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:181
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:182
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:183
verses.text: You are caught unawares in your own snare.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:184
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:185
verses.text: How so?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:186
verses.text: You quote our Lord's utterance to the effect that a man can be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:187
verses.text: For when He says, "If thou wilt be perfect, sell all that thou hast, and give to the poor, and come, follow Me," He shows that a man, if he chooses, and if he does what is commanded, can be perfect?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:188
verses.text: You have given me such a terrible blow that I am almost dazed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:189
verses.text: But yet the very words you quote, "If thou wilt be perfect," were spoken to one who could not, or rather would not, and, therefore, could not; show me now, as you promised, some one who would and could.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:190
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:191
verses.text: Why am I compelled to produce instances of perfection, when it is clear from what the Saviour said to one, and through one to all, "If thou wilt be perfect" that it is possible for men to be perfect?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:192
verses.text: That is a mere shuffle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:193
verses.text: You still stick fast in the mire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:194
verses.text: For, either, if a thing is possible, it has occurred at some time or other; or, if it never has happened, grant that it is impossible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:195
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:196
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:197
verses.text: Why do I any longer delay? You must be vanquished by the authority or Scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:198
verses.text: To pass over other passages, you must be silenced by the two in which we read the praises of Job, and of Zacharias and Elizabeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:199
verses.text: For, unless I am deceived, it is thus written in the book of Job: "There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was perfect and upright, a true worshipper of God, and one who kept himself from every evil thing".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:200
verses.text: And again:"Who is he that reproveth one that is righteous and free from sin, and speaketh words without knowledge?" Also, in the Gospel according to Luke, we read:"There was in the days of Herod, king of Judaea, a certain priest named Zacharias, of the course of Abijah: and he had a wife of the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:201
verses.text: And they were both righteous before God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:202
verses.text: If a true worshipper of God is also without spot and without offence, and if those who walked in all the ordinances of the Lord are righteous before God, I suppose they are free from sin, and lack nothing that pertains to righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:203
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:204
verses.text: You have cited passages which have been detached not only from the rest of Scripture, but from the books in which they occur.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:205
verses.text: For even Job, after he was stricken with the plague, is convicted of having spoken many things against the ruling of God, and to have summoned Him to the bar: "Would that a man stood with God in the judgment as a son of man stands with his fellow".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:206
verses.text: And again:"Oh that I had one to hear me! that the Almighty might hear my desire, and that the judge would himself write a book!" And again: "Though I be righteous, mine own mouth shall condemn me: though I be perfect, it shall prove me perverse.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:207
verses.text: If I wash myself with snow-water, and make my hands never so clean, Thou hast dyed me again and again with filth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:208
verses.text: Mine own clothes have abhorred me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:209
verses.text: And of Zacharias it is written, that when the angel promised the birth of a son, he said:"Whereby shall I know this? for I am an old man, and my wife well stricken in years".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:210
verses.text: For which answer he was at once condemned to silence: "Thou shalt be silent, and not able to speak, until the day that these things shall come to pass, because thou believest not my words, which shall be fulfilled in their season".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:211
verses.text: From this it is clear that men are called righteous, and said to be without fault; but that, if negligence comes over them, they may fall; and that a man always occupies a middle place, so that he may slip from the height of virtue into vice, or may rise from vice to virtue; and that he is never safe, but must dread shipwreck even in fair weather; and, therefore, that a man cannot be without sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:212
verses.text: Solomon says, "There is not a righteous man upon earth that doeth good and sinneth not"; and likewise in the book of Kings: "There is no man that sinneth not".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:213
verses.text: So, also, the blessed David says: "Who can understand his errors? Cleanse Thou me from hidden faults, and keep back Thy servant from presumptuous sins".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:214
verses.text: And again: "Enter not into judgment with Thy servant, for in Thy sight shall no man living be justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:215
verses.text: Holy Scripture is full of passages to the same effect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:216
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:217
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:218
verses.text: But what answer will you give to the famous declaration of John the Evangelist:"We know that whosoever is begotten of God sinneth not; but the begetting of God keepeth him, and the evil one toucheth him not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:219
verses.text: We know that we are of God, and the whole world lieth in the evil one?"  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:220
verses.text: I will requite like with like, and will show that, according to you, the little epistle of the Evangelist contradicts itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:221
verses.text: For, if whosoever is begotten of God sinneth not because His seed abideth in him, and he cannot sin, because he is born of God, how is it that the writer says in the same place:"If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us?" You cannot explain.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:222
verses.text: You hesitate and are confused.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:223
verses.text: Listen to the same Evangelist telling us that"If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:224
verses.text: We are then righteous when we confess that we are sinners, and our righteousness depends not upon our own merits, but on the mercy of God, as the Holy Scripture says,"The righteous man accuseth himself when he beginneth to speak," and elsewhere,"Tell thy sins that thou mayest be justified".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:225
verses.text: "God hath shut up all under sin, that He may have mercy upon all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:226
verses.text: And the highest righteousness of man is this—whatever virtue he may be able to acquire, not to think it his own, but the gift of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:227
verses.text: He then who is born of God does not sin, so long as the seed of God remains in him, and he cannot sin, because he is born of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:228
verses.text: But seeing that, while the householder slept, an enemy sowed tares, and that when we know not, a sower by night scatters in the Lord's field darnel and wild oats among the good corn, this parable of the householder in the Gospel should excite our fears.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:229
verses.text: He cleanses his floor, and gathers the wheat into his garner, but leaves the chaff to be scattered by the winds, or burned by the fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:230
verses.text: And so we read in Jeremiah, "What is the chaff to the wheat? saith the Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:231
verses.text: The chaff, moreover, is separated from the wheat at the end of the world, a proof that, while we are in the mortal body, chaff is mixed with the wheat.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:232
verses.text: But if you object, and ask why did the Apostle say "and he cannot sin, because he is born of God," I reply by asking you what becomes of the reward of his choice? For if a man does not sin because he cannot sin, free will is destroyed, and goodness cannot possibly be due to his efforts, but must be part of a nature unreceptive of evil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:233
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:234
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:235
verses.text: The task I set you just now was an easy one by way of practice for something more difficult.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:236
verses.text: What have you to say to my next argument? Clever as you are, all your skill will not avail to overthrow it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:237
verses.text: I shall first quote from the Old Testament, then from the New.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:238
verses.text: Moses is the chief figure in the Old Testament, our Lord and Saviour in the New.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:239
verses.text: Moses says to the people,"Be perfect in the sight of the Lord your God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:240
verses.text: And the Saviour bids the Apostles"Be perfect as your heavenly Father is perfect".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:241
verses.text: Now it was either possible for the hearers to do what Moses and the Lord commanded, or, if it be impossible, the fault does not lie with them who cannot obey, but with Him who gave impossible commands.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:242
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:243
verses.text: This passage to the ignorant, and to those who are unaccustomed to meditate on Holy Scripture, and who neither know nor use it, does appear at first sight to favour your opinion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:244
verses.text: But when you look into it, the difficulty soon disappears.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:245
verses.text: And when you compare passages of Scripture with others, that the Holy Spirit may not seem to contradict Himself with changing place and time, according to what is written,"Deep calleth unto deep at the noise of thy water spouts," the truth will show itself, that is, that Christ did give a possible command when He said: "Be ye perfect as your heavenly Father is perfect," and yet that the Apostles were not perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:246
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:247
verses.text: I am not talking of what the Apostles did, but of what Christ commanded.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:248
verses.text: And the fault does not lie with the giver of the command, but with the hearers of it, because we cannot admit the justice of him who commands without conceding the possibility of doing what is commanded.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:249
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:250
verses.text: Good! Don't tell me then that a man can be without sin if he chooses, but that a man can be what the Apostles were not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:251
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:252
verses.text: Do you think me fool enough to dare say such a thing?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:253
verses.text: Although you do not say it in so many words, however reluctant you may be to admit the fact, it follows by natural sequence from your proposition.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:254
verses.text: For if a man can be without sin, and it is clear the Apostles were not without sin, a man can be higher than the Apostles: to say nothing of patriarchs and prophets whose righteousness under the law was not perfect, as the Apostle says, "For all have sinned, and fall short of the glory of God: being justified freely by His grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus: whom God set forth to be a propitiator".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:255
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:256
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:257
verses.text: This way of arguing is intricate and brings the simplicity which becomes the Church into the tangled thickets of philosophy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:258
verses.text: What has Paul to do with Aristotle? or Peter with Plato? For as the latter was the prince of philosophers, so was the former chief of the Apostles: on him the Lord's Church was firmly founded, and neither rushing flood nor storm can shake it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:259
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:260
verses.text: Now you are rhetorical, and while you taunt me with philosophy, you yourself cross over to the camp of the orators.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:261
verses.text: But listen to what your same favourite orator says:"Let us have no more commonplaces: we get them at home".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:262
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:263
verses.text: There is no eloquence in this, no bombast like that of the orators, who might be defined as persons whose object is to persuade, and who frame their language accordingly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:264
verses.text: We are seeking unadulterated truth, and use unsophisticated language.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:265
verses.text: Either the Lord did not give impossible commands, so that they are to blame who did not do what was possible; or, if what is commanded cannot be done, then not they who do not things impossible are convicted of unrighteousness, but He Who commanded things impossible, and that is an impious statement.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:266
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:267
verses.text: I see you are much more disturbed than is your wont; so I will not ply you with arguments.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:268
verses.text: But let me briefly ask what you think of the well-known passage of the Apostle when he wrote to the Philippians: "Not that I have already obtained, or am already made perfect: but I press on, if so be that I may apprehend that for which also I was apprehended by Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:269
verses.text: Brethren, I count not myself to have yet apprehended: but one thing I do; forgetting the things which are behind, and stretching forward to the things which are before, I press on towards the goal unto the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:270
verses.text: Let us, therefore, as many as be perfect, be thus minded: and if in anything ye are otherwise minded, even this shall God reveal unto you," and so on; no doubt you know the rest, which, in my desire to be brief, I omit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:271
verses.text: He says that he had not yet apprehended, and was by no means perfect; but, like an archer, aimed his arrows at the mark set up (more expressively calledσκοπός in Greek), lest the shaft, turning to one side or the other, might show the unskilfulness of the archer.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:272
verses.text: He further declares that he always forgot the past, and ever stretched forward to the things in front, thus teaching that no heed should be paid to the past, but the future earnestly desired; so that what to-day he thought perfect, while he was stretching forward to better things and things in front, to-morrow proves to have been imperfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:273
verses.text: And thus at every step, never standing still, but always running, he shows that to be imperfect which we men thought perfect, and teaches that our only perfection and true righteousness is that which is measured by the excellence of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:274
verses.text: "I press on towards the goal," he says, "unto the prize of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:275
verses.text: Oh, blessed Apostle Paul, pardon me, a poor creature who confess my faults, if I venture to ask a question.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:276
verses.text: You say that you had not yet obtained, nor yet apprehended, nor were yet perfect, and that you always forgot the things behind, and stretched forward to the things in front, if by any means you might have part in the resurrection of the dead, and win the prize of your high calling.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:277
verses.text: How, then, is it that you immediately add, "As many therefore as are perfect are thus minded"? (or, let us be thus minded, for the copies vary).

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:278
verses.text: And what mind is it that we have, or are to have? that we are perfect? that we have apprehended that which we have not apprehended, received what we have not received, are perfect who are not yet perfect? What mind then have we, or rather what mind ought we to have who are not perfect? To confess that we are imperfect, and have not yet apprehended, nor yet obtained, this is true wisdom in man: know thyself to be imperfect; and, if I may so speak, the perfection of all who are righteous, so long as they are in the flesh, is imperfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:279
verses.text: Hence we read in Proverbs: "To understand true righteousness".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:280
verses.text: For if there were not also a false righteousness, the righteousness of God would never be called true.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:281
verses.text: The Apostle continues: "and if ye are otherwise minded, God will also reveal that to you".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:282
verses.text: This sounds strange to my ears.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:283
verses.text: He who but just now said, "Not that I have already obtained, or am already perfect"; the chosen vessel, who was so confident of Christ's dwelling in him that he dared to say "Do ye seek a proof of Christ that speaketh in me? "and yet plainly confessed that he was not perfect; he now gives to the multitude what he denied to himself in particular, he unites himself with the rest and says, "As many of us as are perfect, let us be thus minded".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:284
verses.text: But why he said this, he explains presently.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:285
verses.text: Let us, he means, who wish to be perfect according to the poor measure of human frailty, think this, that we have not yet obtained, nor yet apprehended, nor are yet perfect, and inasmuch as we are not yet perfect, and, perhaps, think otherwise than true and perfect perfection requires, if we are minded otherwise than is dictated by the full knowledge of God, God will also reveal this to us, so that we may pray with David and say, "Open Thou mine eyes that I may behold wondrous things out of Thy law".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:286
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:287
verses.text: All this makes it clear that in Holy Scripture there are two sorts of perfection, two of righteousness, and two of fear.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:288
verses.text: The first is that perfection, and incomparable truth, and perfect righteousnessand fear, which is the beginning of wisdom, and which we must measure by the excellence of God; the second, which is within the range not only of men, but of every creature, and is not inconsistent with our frailty, as we read in the Psalms: "In Thy sight shall no man living be justified," is that righteousness which is said to be perfect, not in comparison with God, but as recognized by God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:289
verses.text: Job, and Zacharias, and Elizabeth, were called righteous, in respect of that righteousness which might some day turn to unrighteousness, and not in respect of that which is incapable of change, concerning which it is said,"I am God, and change not".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:290
verses.text: And this is that which the Apostle elsewhere writes: "That which hath been made glorious hath not been made glorious in this respect, by reason of the glory that surpasseth"; because, that is, the righteousness of the law, in comparison of the grace of the Gospel, does not seem to be righteousness at all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:291
verses.text: For if," he says, that which passeth away was with glory, much more that which remaineth is in glory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:292
verses.text: And again, "We know in part, and we prophesy in part; but when that which is perfect is come, that which is in part shall be done away".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:293
verses.text: And,"For now we see in a mirror, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shall I know even as also I have been known".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:294
verses.text: And in the Psalms,"Such knowledge is too wonderful for me; it is high, I cannot attain unto it".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:295
verses.text: And again,"When I thought how I might know this, it was too painful for me; until I went into the sanctuary of God, and considered their latter end".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:296
verses.text: And in the same place, "I was as a beast before thee: nevertheless I am continually with thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:297
verses.text: And Jeremiah says, "Every man is become brutish and without knowledge".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:298
verses.text: And to return to the Apostle Paul, "The foolishness of God is wiser than men".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:299
verses.text: And much besides, which I omit for brevity's sake.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:300
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:301
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:302
verses.text: My dear Atticus, your speech is really a clever feat of memory.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:303
verses.text: But the labour you have spent in mustering this host of authorities is to my advantage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:304
verses.text: For I do not any more than you compare man with God, but with other men, in comparison with whom he who takes the trouble can be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:305
verses.text: And so, when we say that man, if he chooses, can be without sin, the standard is the measure of man, not the majesty of God, in comparison with Whom no creature can be perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:306
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:307
verses.text: Critobulus, I am obliged to you for reminding me of the fact.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:308
verses.text: For it is just my own view that no creature can be perfect in respect of true and finished righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:309
verses.text: But that one differs from another, and that one man's righteousness is not the same as another's, no one doubts; nor again that one may be greater or less than another, and yet that, relatively to their own status and capacity, men may be called righteous who are not righteous when compared with others.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:310
verses.text: For instance, the Apostle Paul, the chosen vessel who laboured more than all the Apostles, was, I suppose, righteous when he wrote to Timothy, "I have fought the good fight, I have finished the course, I have kept the faith: henceforth there is laid up for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge, shall give to me at that day: and not only to me, but also to all them that love His appearing".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:311
verses.text: Timothy, his disciple and imitator, whom he taught the rules of action and the limits of virtue, was also righteous.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:312
verses.text: Are we to think there was one and the same righteousness in them both, and that he had not more merit who laboured more than all? "In my Father's house are many mansions".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:313
verses.text: I suppose there are also different degrees of merit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:314
verses.text: "One star differeth from another star in glory," and in the one body of the Church there are different members.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:315
verses.text: The sun has its own splendour, the moon tempers the darkness of the night; and the five heavenly bodies which are called planets traverse the sky in different tracks and with different degrees of luminousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:316
verses.text: There are countless other stars whose movements we trace in the firmament.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:317
verses.text: Each has its own brightness, and though each in respect of its own is perfect, yet, in comparison with one of greater magnitude, it lacks perfection.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:318
verses.text: In the body also with its different members, the eye has one function, the hand another, the foot another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:319
verses.text: Whence the Apostle says, "The eye cannot say to the hand, I have no need of thee: or again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:320
verses.text: Are all Apostles? are all prophets? are all teachers? are all workers of miracles? have all gifts of healing? do all speak with tongues? do all interpret? But desire earnestly the greater gifts.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:321
verses.text: But all these worketh the one and the same Spirit, dividing to each one severally even as He will".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:322
verses.text: And here mark carefully that he does not say, as each member desires, but as the Spirit Himself will.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:323
verses.text: For the vessel cannot say to him that makes it, "Why dost thou make me thus or thus? Hath not the potter a right over the clay, from the same lump to make one part a vessel unto honour, and another unto dishonour?" And so in close sequence he added, "Desire earnestly the greater gifts," so that, by the exercise of faith and diligence, we may win something in addition to other gifts, and may be superior to those who, compared with us, are in the second or third class.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:324
verses.text: In a great house there are different vessels, some of gold, some of silver, brass, iron, wood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:325
verses.text: And yet while in its kind a vessel of brass is perfect, in comparison with one of silver it is called imperfect, and again one of silver, compared with one of gold, is inferior.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:326
verses.text: And thus, when compared with one another, all things are imperfect and perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:327
verses.text: In a field of good soil, and from one sowing, there springs a crop thirty-fold, sixty-fold, or a hundred-fold.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:328
verses.text: The very numbers show that there is disparity in the parts of the produce, and yet in its own kind each is perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:329
verses.text: Elizabeth and Zacharias, whom you adduce and with whom you cover yourself as with an impenetrable shield, may teach us how far they are beneath the holiness of blessed Mary, the Lord's Mother, who, conscious that God was dwelling in her, proclaims without reserve, "Behold, from henceforth all generations shall call me blessed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:330
verses.text: For He that is mighty hath done to me great things; and holy is His name.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:331
verses.text: And His mercy is unto generations and generations of them that fear Him: He hath showed strength with His arm".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:332
verses.text: Where, observe, she says she is blessed not by her own merit and virtue, but by the mercy of God dwelling in her.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:333
verses.text: And John himself, a greater than whom has not arisen among the sons of men, is better than his parents.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:334
verses.text: For not only does our Lord compare him with men, but with angels also.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:335
verses.text: And yet he, who was greater on earth than all other men, is said to be less than the least in the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:336
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:337
verses.text: Need we be surprised that, when saints are compared, some are better, some worse, since the same holds good in the comparison of sins? To Jerusalem, pierced and wounded with many sins, it is said, "Sodom is justified by thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:338
verses.text: It is not because Sodom, which has sunk for ever into ashes, is just in herself, that it is said by Ezekiel, "Sodom shall be restored to her former estate"; but that, in comparison with the more accursed Jerusalem, she appears just.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:339
verses.text: For Jerusalem killed the Son of God; Sodom through fulness of bread and excessive luxury carried her lust beyond all bounds.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:340
verses.text: The publican in the Gospel who smote upon his breast as though it were a magazine of the worst thoughts, and, conscious of his offences, dared not lift up his eyes, is justified rather than the proud Pharisee.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:341
verses.text: And Thamar in the guise of a harlot deceived Judah, and in the estimation of this man himself who was deceived, was worthy of the words, "Thamar is more righteous than I".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:342
verses.text: All this goes to prove that not only in comparison with Divine majesty are men far from perfection, but also when compared with angels, and other men who have climbed the heights of virtue.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:343
verses.text: You may be superior to some one whom you have shown to be imperfect, and yet be outstripped by another; and consequently may not have true perfection, which, if it be perfect, is absolute.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:344
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:345
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:346
verses.text: How is it then, Atticus, that the Divine Word urges us to perfection?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:347
verses.text: I have already explained that in proportion to our strength each one, with all his power, must stretch forward, if by any means he may attain to, and apprehend the reward of his high calling.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:348
verses.text: In short Almighty God, to whom, as the Apostle teaches, the Son must in accordance with the dispensation of the Incarnation be subjected, that"God may be all in all," clearly shows that all things are by no means subject to Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:349
verses.text: Hence the prophet anticipates his own final subjection, saying, "Shall not my soul be subject to God alone? for of Him cometh my salvation".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:350
verses.text: And because in the body of the Church Christ is the head, and some of the members still resist, the body does not appear to be subject even to the head.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:351
verses.text: For if one member suffer, all the members suffer with it, and the whole body is tortured by the pain in one member.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:352
verses.text: My meaning may be more clearly expressed thus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:353
verses.text: So long as we have the treasure in earthen vessels, and are clothed with frail flesh, or rather with mortal and corruptible flesh, we think ourselves fortunate if, in single virtues and separate portions of virtue, we are subject to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:354
verses.text: But when this mortal shall have put on immortality, and this corruptible shall have put on incorruption, and death shall be swallowed up in the victory of Christ, then will God be all in all: and so there will not be merely wisdom in Solomon, sweetness in David, zeal in Elias and Phinees, faith in Abraham, perfect love in Peter, to whom it was said, "Simon, son of John, lovest thou me?" zeal for preaching in the chosen vessel, and two or three virtues each in others, but God will be wholly in all, and the company of the saints will rejoice in the whole band of virtues, and God will be all in all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:355
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:356
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:357
verses.text: Do I understand you to say that no saint, so long as he is in this poor body, can have all virtues?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:358
verses.text: Just so, because now we prophesy in part, and know in part.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:359
verses.text: It is impossible for all things to be in all men, for no son of man is immortal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:360
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:361
verses.text: How is it, then, that we read that he who has one virtue appears to have all?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:362
verses.text: By partaking of them, not possessing them, for individuals must excel in particular virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:363
verses.text: But I confess I don't know where to find what you say you have read.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:364
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:365
verses.text: Are you not aware that the philosophers take that view?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:366
verses.text: The philosophers may, but the Apostles do not.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:367
verses.text: I heed not what Aristotle, but what Paul, teaches.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:368
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:369
verses.text: Pray does not James the Apostle write that he who stumbles in one point is guilty of all?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:370
verses.text: The passage is its own interpreter.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:371
verses.text: James did not say, as a starting-point for the discussion, he who prefers a rich man to a poor man in honour is guilty of adultery or murder.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:372
verses.text: That is a delusion of the Stoics who maintain the equality of sins.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:373
verses.text: But he proceeds thus: "He who said, Thou shalt not commit adultery, said also, Thou shalt not kill: but although thou dost not kill, yet, if thou commit adultery, thou art become a transgressor of the law".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:374
verses.text: Light offences are compared with light ones, and heavy offences with heavy ones.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:375
verses.text: A fault that deserves the rod must not be avenged with the sword; nor must a crime worthy of the sword, be checked with the rod.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:376
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:377
verses.text: Suppose it true that no saint has all the virtues: you will surely grant that within the range of his ability, if a man do what he can, he is perfect.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:378
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:379
verses.text: Do you not remember what I said before?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:380
verses.text: What was it?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:381
verses.text: That a man is perfect in respect of what he has done, imperfect in respect of what he could not do.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:382
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:383
verses.text: But as he is perfect in respect of what he has done, because he willed to do it, so in respect of that which constitutes him imperfect, because he has not done it, he might have been perfect, had he willed to do it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:384
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:385
verses.text: Who does not wish to do what is perfect? Or who does not long to grow vigorously in all virtue? If you look for all virtues in each individual, you do away with the distinctions of things, and the difference of graces, and the variety of the work of the Creator, whose prophet cries aloud in the sacred song: "In wisdom hast thou made them all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:386
verses.text: Lucifer may be indignant because he has not the brightness of the moon.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:387
verses.text: The moon may dispute over her eclipses and ceaseless toil, and ask why she must traverse every month the yearly orbit of the sun.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:388
verses.text: The sun may complain and want to know what he has done that he travels more slowly than the moon.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:389
verses.text: And we poor creatures may demand to know why it is that we were made men and not angels; although your teacher,the Ancient, the fountain from which these streams flow, asserts that all rational creatures were created equal and started fairly, like charioteers, either to succumb halfway, or to pass on rapidly and reach the wished-for goal.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:390
verses.text: Elephants, with their huge bulk, and griffins, might discuss their ponderous frames and ask why they must go on four feet, while flies, midges, and other creatures like them have six feet under their tiny wings, and there are some creeping things which have such an abundance of feet that the keenest vision cannot follow their countless and simultaneous movements.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:391
verses.text: Marcion and all the heretics who denied the Creator's works might speak thus.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:392
verses.text: Your principle goes so far that while its adherents attack particular points, they are laying hands on God; they are asking why He only is God, why He envies the creatures, and why they are not all endowed with the same power and importance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:393
verses.text: You would not say so much (for you are not mad enough to openly fight against God), yet this is your meaning in other words, when you give man an attribute of God, and make him to be without sin like God Himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:394
verses.text: Hence the Apostle, with his voice of thunder, says, concerning different graces: "There are diversities of gifts, but the same spirit; and differences of ministrations, but the same Lord; and there are diversities of workings, but the same God, Who worketh all things in all".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:395
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:396
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:397
verses.text: You push this one particular point too far in seeking to convince me that a man cannot have all excellences at the same time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:398
verses.text: As though God were guilty of envy, or unable to bestow upon His image and likeness a correspondence in all things to his Creator.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:399
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:400
verses.text: Is it I or you who go too far? You revive questions already settled, and do not understand that likeness is one thing, equality another; that the former is a painting, the latter, reality.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:401
verses.text: A real horse courses over the plains; the painted one with his chariot does not leave the wall.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:402
verses.text: The Arians do not allow to the Son of God what you give to every man.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:403
verses.text: Some do not dare to confess the perfect humanity of Christ, lest they should be compelled to accept the belief that He had the sins of a man as though the Creator were unequal to the act of creating, and the title Son of Man were co-extensive with the title Son of God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:404
verses.text: So either set me something else to answer, or lay aside pride and give glory to God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:405
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:406
verses.text: You forget a former answer of yours, and have been so busy forging your chain of argument, and careering through the wide fields of Scripture, like a horse that has slipped its bridle, that you have not said a single word about the main point.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:407
verses.text: Your forgetfulness is a pretext for escaping the necessity of a reply.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:408
verses.text: It was foolish in me to concede to you for the nonce what you asked, and to suppose that you would voluntarily give up what you had received, and would not need a reminder to make you pay what you owed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:409
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:410
verses.text: If I mistake not, it was the question of possible commands of which I deferred the answer.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:411
verses.text: Pray proceed as you think best.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:412
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:413
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:414
verses.text: The commands which God has given are either possible or impossible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:415
verses.text: If possible, it is in our power to do them, if we choose.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:416
verses.text: If impossible, we cannot be held guilty for omitting duties which it is not given us to fulfill.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:417
verses.text: Hence it results that, whether God has given possible or impossible commands, a man can be without sin if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:418
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:419
verses.text: I beg your patient attention, for what we seek is not victory over an opponent, but the triumph of truth over falsehood.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:420
verses.text: God has put within the power of mankind all arts, for we see that a vast number of men have mastered them.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:421
verses.text: To pass over those which the Greeks callβάναυσοι, as we may say, the manual arts, I will instance grammar, rhetoric, the three sorts of philosophy—physics, ethics, logic—geometry also, and astronomy, astrology, arithmetic, music, which are also parts of philosophy; medicine, too, in its threefold division—theory, investigation, practice; a knowledge of law in general and of particular enactments.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:422
verses.text: Which of us, however clever he may be, will be able to understand them all, when the most eloquent of orators, discussing rhetoric and jurisprudence, said: "A few may excel in one, in both no one can".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:423
verses.text: You see, then, that God has commanded what is possible, and yet, that no one can by nature attain to what is possible.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:424
verses.text: Similarly he has given different rules and various virtues, all of which we cannot possess at the same time.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:425
verses.text: Hence it happens that a virtue which in one person takes the chief place, or is found in perfection, in another is but partial; and yet, he is not to blame who has not all excellence, nor is he condemned for lacking that which he has not; but he is justified through what he does possess.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:426
verses.text: The Apostle described the character of a bishop when he wrote to Timothy, "The bishop, therefore, must be without reproach, the husband of one wife, temperate, modest, orderly, given to hospitality, apt to teach; no brawler, no striker; but gentle, not contentious, no lover of money; one that ruleth well his own house, having his children in subjection with all modesty".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:427
verses.text: And again, "Not a novice, lest, being puffed up, he fall into the condemnation of the devil.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:428
verses.text: Moreover, he must have good testimony from them that are without, lest he fall into reproach and the snare of the devil".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:429
verses.text: Writing also to his disciple Titus, he briefly points out what sort of bishops he ought to ordain:"For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that were wanting, and appoint elders in every city, as I gave thee charge; if any man is blameless, the husband of one wife, having children that believe, who are not accused of riot or unruly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:430
verses.text: For the bishop must be blameless (or free from accusation, for so much is conveyed by the original) as God's steward; not self-willed, not soon angry, no brawler, no striker, not greedy of filthy lucre; but given to hospitality, kind, modest, just, holy, temperate; holding to the faithful word which is according to the teaching, that he may be able both to exhort in the sound doctrine, and to convict the gainsayers".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:431
verses.text: I will not now say anything of the various rules relating to different persons, but will confine myself to the commands connected with the bishop.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:432
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:433
verses.text: God certainly wishes bishops or priests to be such as the chosen vessel teaches they should be.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:434
verses.text: As to the first qualification it is seldom or never that one is found without reproach; for who is it that has not some fault, like a mole or a wart on a lovely body? If the Apostle himself says of Peter that he did not tread a straight path in the truth of the Gospel, and was so far to blame that even Barnabas was led away into the same dissimulation, who will be indignant if that is denied to him which the chief of the Apostles had not? Then, supposing you find one, "the husband of one wife, sober-minded, orderly, given to hospitality," the next attribute—διδακτικόν , apt to teach, not merely as the Latin renders the word, apt to be taught—you will hardly find in company with the other virtues.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:435
verses.text: A bishop or priest that is a brawler, or a striker, or a lover of money, the Apostle rejects, and in his stead would have one gentle, not contentious, free from avarice, one that rules well his own house, and what is very hard, one who has his children in subjection with all modesty, whether they be children of the flesh or children of the faith.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:436
verses.text: "With all modesty," he says.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:437
verses.text: It is not enough for him to have his own modesty unless it be enhanced by the modesty of his children, companions, and servants, as David says, "He that walketh in a perfect way, he shall minister unto me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:438
verses.text: Let us consider, also, the emphasis laid on modesty by the addition of the words "having his children in subjection with all modesty".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:439
