verses.text: Not only in deed but in word and gesture must he hold aloof from immodesty, lest perchance the experience of Eli be his.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:440
verses.text: Eli certainly rebuked his sons, saying, "Nay, my sons, nay; it is not a good report which I hear of you".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:441
verses.text: He chided them, and yet was punished, because he should not have chided, but cast them off.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:442
verses.text: What will he do who rejoices at vice or lacks the courage to correct it? Who fears his own conscience, and therefore pretends to be ignorant of what is in everybody's mouth? The next point is that the bishop must be free from accusation, that he have a good report from them who are without, that no reproaches of opponents be levelled at him, and that they who dislike his doctrine may be pleased with his life.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:443
verses.text: I suppose it would not be easy to find all this, and particularly one "able to resist the gain-sayers," to check and overcome erroneous opinions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:444
verses.text: He wishes no novice to be ordained bishop, and yet in our time we see the youthful novice sought after as though he represented the highest righteousness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:445
verses.text: If baptism immediately made a man righteous, and full of all righteousness, it was of course idle for the Apostle to repel a novice; but baptism annuls old sins, does not bestow new virtues; it looses from prison, and promises rewards to the released if he will work.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:446
verses.text: Seldom or never, I say, is there a man who has all the virtues which a bishop should have.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:447
verses.text: And yet if a bishop lacked one or two of the virtues in the list, it does not follow that he can no longer be called righteous, nor will he be condemned for his deficiencies, but will be crowned for what he has.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:448
verses.text: For to have all and lack nothing is the virtue of Him "Who did no sin; neither was guile found in His mouth; Who, when He was reviled, reviled not again;" Who, confident in the consciousness of virtue, said, "Behold the prince of this world cometh, and findeth nothing in me;""Who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be on an equality with God, but emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant, and became obedient unto death, even the death of the cross.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:449
verses.text: Wherefore God gave Him the name which is above every name, that at the name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven, and things on earth, and things under the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:450
verses.text: If, then, in the person of a single bishop you will either not find at all, or with difficulty, even a few of the things commanded, how will you deal with the mass of men in general who are bound to fulfil all the commandments?  23.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:451
verses.text: Let us reason from things bodily to things spiritual.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:452
verses.text: One man is swift-footed, but not strong-handed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:453
verses.text: That man's movements are slow, but he stands firm in battle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:454
verses.text: This man has a fine face, but a harsh voice: another is repulsive to look at, but sings sweetly and melodiously.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:455
verses.text: There we see a man of great ability, but equally poor memory; here is another whose memory serves him, but whose wits are slow.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:456
verses.text: In the very discussions with which when we were boys we amused ourselves, all the disputants are not on a level, either in introducing a subject, or in narrative, or in digressions, or wealth of illustration, and charm of peroration, but their various oratorical efforts exhibit different degrees of merit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:457
verses.text: Of churchmen I will say more.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:458
verses.text: Many discourse well upon the Gospels, but in explaining an Apostle's meaning are unequal to themselves.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:459
verses.text: Others, although most acute in the New Testament are dumb in the Psalms and the Old Testament.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:460
verses.text: I quite agree with Virgil—Non omnia possumus omnes; and seldom or never is the rich man found who in the abundance of his wealth has everything in equal proportions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:461
verses.text: That God has given possible commands, I admit no less than you.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:462
verses.text: But it is not for each one of us to make all these possible virtues our own, not because our nature is weak, for that is a slander upon God, but because our hearts and minds grow weary and cannot keep all virtues simultaneously and perpetually.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:463
verses.text: And if you blame the Creator for having made you subject to weariness and failure, I shall reply, your censure would be still more severe if you thought proper to accuse Him of not having made you God.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:464
verses.text: But you will say, if I have not the power, no sin attaches to me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:465
verses.text: You have sinned because you have not done what another could do.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:466
verses.text: And again, he in comparison with whom you are inferior will be a sinner in respect of some other virtue, relatively to you or to another person; and thus it happens that whoever is thought to be first, is inferior to him who is his superior in some other particular.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:467
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:468
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:469
verses.text: If it is impossible for man to be without sin, what does the Apostle Jude mean by writing, "Now unto Him that is able to keep you without sin, and to set you before the presence of His glory without blemish"? This is clear proof that it is possible to keep a man without sin and without blemish.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:470
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:471
verses.text: You do not understand the passage.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:472
verses.text: We are not told that a man can be without sin, which is your view, but that God, if He chooses, can keep a man free from sin, and of His mercy guard him so that he may be without blemish.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:473
verses.text: And I say that all things are possible with God; but that everything which a man desires is not possible to him, and especially, an attribute which belongs to no created thing you ever read of.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:474
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:475
verses.text: I do not say that a man is without sin, which, perhaps, appears to you to be possible; but that he may be, if he chooses.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:476
verses.text: For actuality is one thing, possibility another.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:477
verses.text: In the actual we look for an instance; possibility implies that our power to act is real.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:478
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:479
verses.text: You are trifling, and forget the proverb, "Don't do what is done".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:480
verses.text: You keep turning in the same mire, and only make more dirt.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:481
verses.text: I shall, therefore, tell you, what is clear to all, that you are trying to establish a thing that is not, never was, and, perhaps, never will be.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:482
verses.text: To employ your own words, and show the folly and inconsistency of your argument, I say that you are maintaining an impossible possibility.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:483
verses.text: For your proposition, that a man can be without sin if he chooses, is either true or false.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:484
verses.text: If it be true, show me who the man is; if it be false, whatever is false can never happen.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:485
verses.text: But let us have no more of these notions.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:486
verses.text: Hissed off the stage, and no longer daring to appear in public, they should stay on the book shelves, and not let themselves be heard.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:487
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:488
verses.text: Let us proceed to other matters.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:489
verses.text: And here I must speak uninterruptedly, so far, at least, as is consistent with giving you an opportunity of refuting me, or asking any question you think fit.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:490
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:491
verses.text: I will listen patiently, though I cannot say gladly.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:492
verses.text: The ability of your reasoning will strike me all the more, while I am amazed at its falsity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:493
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:494
verses.text: Whether what I am going to say is true or false, you will be able to judge when you have heard it.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:495
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:496
verses.text: Follow your own method.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:497
verses.text: I am resolved, if I am unable to answer, to hold my tongue rather than assent to a lie.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:498
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:499
verses.text: What difference does it make whether I defeat you speaking or silent, and, as it is in the story of Proteus, catch you asleep or awake?  C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:500
verses.text: When you have said what you like, you shall hear what you will certainly not like.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:501
verses.text: For though truth may be put to hard shifts it cannot be subdued.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:502
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:503
verses.text: I want to sift your opinions a little, that your followers may know what an inspired genius you are.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:504
verses.text: You say, "It is impossible for any but those who have the knowledge of the law to be without sin"; and you, consequently, shut out from righteousness a large number of Christians, and, preacher of sinlessness though you are, declare nearly all to be sinners.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:505
verses.text: For how many Christians have that knowledge of the law which you can find but seldom, or hardly at all, in many doctors of the Church? But your liberality is so great that, in order to stand well with your Amazons, you have elsewhere written, "Even women ought to have a knowledge of the law," although the Apostle preaches that women ought to keep silence in the churches, and if they want to know anything consult their husbands at home.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:506
verses.text: And you are not content with having given your cohort a knowledge of Scripture, but you must delight yourself with their songs and canticles, for you have a heading to the effect that "Women also should sing unto God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:507
verses.text: Who does not know that women should sing in the privacy of their own rooms, away from the company of men and the crowded congregation? But you allow what is not lawful, and the consequence is, that, with the support of their master, they make an open show of that which should be done with modesty, and with no eye to witness.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:508
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:509
verses.text: You go on to say, "The servant of God should utter from his lips no bitterness, but ever that which is sweet and pleasant"; and as though a servant of God were one thing, a doctor and priest of the Church another, forgetting what was previously laid down, you say in another heading, "A priest or doctor ought to watch the actions of all, and confidently rebuke sinners, lest he be responsible for them and their blood be required at his hands".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:510
verses.text: And, not satisfied with saying it once, you repeat it, and inculcate that, "A priest or doctor should flatter no one, but boldly rebuke all, lest he destroy both himself and those who hear him".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:511
verses.text: Is there so little harmony in one and the same work that you do not know what you have previously said? For if the servant of God ought to utter no bitterness from his mouth, but always that which is sweet and pleasant, it follows either that a priest and doctor will not be servants of God who ought to confidently rebuke sinners, and flatter no one, but boldly reprove all: or, if a priest and a doctor are not only servants of God, but have the chief place among His servants, it is idle to reserve smooth and pleasant speeches for the servants of God, for these are characteristic of heretics and of them who wish to deceive; as the Apostle says, "They that are such serve not our Lord Christ but their own belly, and by their smooth and fair speech they beguile the hearts of the innocent".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:512
verses.text: Flattery is always insidious, crafty, and smooth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:513
verses.text: And the flatterer is well described by the philosophers as "a pleasant enemy".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:514
verses.text: Truth is bitter, of gloomy visage and wrinkled brow, and distasteful to those who are rebuked.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:515
verses.text: Hence the Apostle says, "Am I become your enemy, because I tell you the truth?" And the comic poet tells us that "Obsequiousness is the mother of friendship, truth of enmity".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:516
verses.text: Wherefore we also eat the Passover with bitter herbs, and the chosen vessel teaches that the Passover should be kept with truth and sincerity.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:517
verses.text: Let truth in our case be plain speaking, and bitterness will instantly follow.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:518
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:519
verses.text: In another place you maintain that "All are governed by their own free choice".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:520
verses.text: What Christian can bear to hear this? For if not one, nor a few, nor many, but all of us are governed by our own free choice, what becomes of the help of God? And how do you explain the text, "A man's goings are ordered by the Lord"? And "A man's way is not in himself"; and "No one can receive anything, unless it be given him from above"; and elsewhere, "What hast thou which thou didst not receive? But if thou didst receive it, why dost thou glory as if thou hadst not received it?" Our Lord and Saviour says:"I am come down from heaven not to do Mine own will, but the will of the Father who sent Me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:521
verses.text: And in another place, "Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from Me; nevertheless not My will, but Thine be done".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:522
verses.text: And in the Lord's prayer, "Thy will be done as in heaven, so on earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:523
verses.text: How is it that you are so rash as to do away with all God's help? Elsewhere, you make a vain attempt to append the words "not without the grace of God"; but in what sense you would have them understood is clear from this passage, for you do not admit His grace in separate actions, but connect it with our creation, the gift of the law, and the power of free will.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:524
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:525
verses.text: The argument of the next section is, "In the day of judgment, no mercy will be shown to the unjust and to sinners, but they must be consumed in eternal fire".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:526
verses.text: Who can bear this, and suffer you to prohibit the mercy of God, and to sit in judgment on the sentence of the Judge before the day of judgment, so that, if He wished to show mercy to the unjust and the sinners, He must not, because you have given your veto? For you say it is written in the one hundred and fourth Psalm, "Let sinners cease to be in the earth, and the wicked be no more".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:527
verses.text: And in Isaiah, "The wicked and sinners shall be burned up together, and they who forsake God shall be consumed".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:528
verses.text: Do you not know that mercy is sometimes blended with the threatenings of God? He does not say that they must be burnt with eternal fires, but let them cease to be in the earth, and the wicked be no more.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:529
verses.text: For it is one thing for them to desist from sin and wickedness, another for them to perish for ever and be burnt in eternal fire.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:530
verses.text: And as for the passage which you quote from Isaiah, "Sinners and the wicked shall be burned up together," he does not add for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:531
verses.text: "And they who forsake God shall be consumed".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:532
verses.text: This properly refers to heretics, who leave the straight path of the faith, and shall be consumed if they will not return to the Lord whom they have forsaken.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:533
verses.text: And the same sentence is ready for you if you neglect to turn to better things.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:534
verses.text: Again, is it not marvellous temerity to couple the wicked and sinners with the impious, for the distinction between them is great? Every impious person is wicked and a sinner; but we cannot conversely say every sinner and wicked person is also impious, for impiety properly belongs to those who have not the knowledge of God, or, if they have once had it, lose it by transgression.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:535
verses.text: But the wounds of sin and wickedness, like faults in general, admit of healing.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:536
verses.text: Hence, it is written, "Many are the scourges of the sinner"; it is not said that he is eternally destroyed.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:537
verses.text: And through all the scourging and torture the faults of Israel are corrected,"For whom the Lord loveth He chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom He receiveth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:538
verses.text: It is one thing to smite with the affection of a teacher and a parent; another to be madly cruel towards adversaries.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:539
verses.text: Wherefore, we sing in the first Psalm, "The impious do not rise in the judgment," for they are already sentenced to destruction; "nor sinners in the counsel of the just".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:540
verses.text: To lose the glory of the resurrection is a different thing from perishing for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:541
verses.text: "The hour cometh," he says, "In which all that are in the tombs shall hear His voice, and shall come forth: they that have done good unto the resurrection of life, and they that have done ill unto the resurrection of judgment".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:542
verses.text: And so the Apostle, in the same sense, because in the same Spirit, says to the Romans,"As many as have sinned without law shall also perish without law; and as many as have sinned under law, shall be judged by law".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:543
verses.text: The man without law is the unbeliever who will perish for ever.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:544
verses.text: Under the law is the sinner who believes in God, and who will be judged by the law, and will not perish.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:545
verses.text: If the wicked and sinners are to be burned with everlasting fire, are you not afraid of the sentence you pass on yourself, seeing that you admit you are wicked and a sinner, while still you argue that a man is not without sin, but that he may be.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:546
verses.text: It follows that the only person who can be saved is an individual who never existed, does not exist, and perhaps never will, and that all our predecessors of whom we read must perish.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:547
verses.text: Take your own case.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:548
verses.text: You are puffed up with all the pride of Cato, and haveMilo's giant shoulders; but is it not amazing temerity for you, who are a sinner, to take the name of a teacher? If you are righteous, and, with a false humility, say you are a sinner, we may be surprised, but we shall rejoice at having so unique a treasure, and at reckoning amongst our friends a personage unknown to patriarch, prophet, and Apostle.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:549
verses.text: And if Origen does maintain that no rational creatures ought to be lost, and allows repentance to the devil, what is that to us, who say that the devil and his attendants, and all impious persons and transgressors, perish eternally, and thatChristians, if they be overtaken by sin, must be saved after they have been punished?  29.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:550
verses.text: Besides all this you add two chapters which contradict one another, and which, if true, would effectually close your mouth.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:551
verses.text: "Except a man have learned, he cannot be acquainted with wisdom and understand the Scriptures".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:552
verses.text: And again, "He that has not been taught, ought not to assume that he knows the law".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:553
verses.text: You must, then, either produce the master from whom you learned, if you are lawfully to claim the knowledge of the law; or, if your master is a person who never learned from any one else, and taught you what he did nor know himself, it follows that you are not acting rightly in claiming a knowledge of Scripture, when you have not been taught, and in starting as a master before you have been a disciple.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:554
verses.text: And yet, perhaps, with your customary humility, you make your boast that the Lord Himself, Who teaches all knowledge, was your master, and that, like Moses in the cloud and darkness, face to face, you hear the words of God, and so, with thehalo round your head, take the lead of us.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:555
verses.text: And even this is not enough, but all at once you turn Stoic, and thunder in our ears Zeno's proud maxims.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:556
verses.text: "A Christian ought to be so patient that if any one wished to take his property he would let it go with joy".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:557
verses.text: Is it not enough for us patiently to lose what we have, without returning thanks to him who ill-treats and plunders us, and sending after him all blessings? The Gospel teaches that to him who would go to law with us, and by strife and litigation take away our coat, we must give our cloak also.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:558
verses.text: It does not enjoin the giving of thanks and joy at the loss of our property.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:559
verses.text: What I say is this, not that there is any enormity in your view, but that everywhere you are prone to exaggeration, and indulge in ambitious flights.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:560
verses.text: This is why you add that "The bravery of dress and ornament is an enemy of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:561
verses.text: What enmity, I should like to know, is there towards God if my tunic is cleaner than usual, or if the bishop, priest, or deacon, or any other ecclesiastics, at the offering of the sacrifices walk in white? Beware, ye clergy; beware, ye monks; widows and virgins, you are in peril unless the people see you begrimed with dirt, and clad in rags.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:562
verses.text: I say nothing of lay-men, who proclaim open war and enmity against God if they wear costly and elegant apparel.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:563
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:564
verses.text: Let us hear the rest.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:565
verses.text: "We must love our enemies as we do our neighbours"; and immediately, falling into a deep slumber, you lay down this proposition: "We must never believe an enemy".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:566
verses.text: Not a word is needed from me to show the contradiction here.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:567
verses.text: You will say that both propositions are found in Scripture, but you do not observe the particular connection in which the passages occur.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:568
verses.text: I am told to love my enemies and pray for my persecutors.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:569
verses.text: Am I bidden to love them as though they were my neighbours, kindred, and friends, and to make no difference between a rival and a relative? If I love my enemies as my neighbours, what more affection can I show to my friends? If you had maintained this position, you ought to have taken care not to contradict yourself by saying that we must never believe an enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:570
verses.text: But even the law teaches us how an enemy should be loved.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:571
verses.text: If an enemy's beast be fallen, we must raise it up.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:572
verses.text: And the Apostle tells us,"If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:573
verses.text: For by so doing thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head," not by way of curse and condemnation, as most people think, but to chasten and bring him to repentance, so that, overcome by kindness, and melted by the warmth of love, he may no longer be an enemy.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:574
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:575
verses.text: Your next point is that "the kingdom of heaven is promised even in the Old Testament," and you adduce evidence from the Apocrypha, although it is clear that the kingdom of heaven was first preached under the Gospel by John the Baptist, and our Lord and Saviour, and the Apostles.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:576
verses.text: Read the Gospels.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:577
verses.text: John the Baptist cries in the desert, "Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand"; and concerning the Saviour it is written, "From that time He began to preach and to say, Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:578
verses.text: And again,"Jesus went round about the towns and villages, teaching in their synagogues, and preaching the kingdom of God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:579
verses.text: And He commanded His Apostles to"go and preach, saying, the kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:580
verses.text: But you call us Manichaeans because we prefer the Gospel to the law, and say that in the latter we have the shadow, in the former, the substance, and you do not see that your foolishness goes hand in hand with impudence.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:581
verses.text: It is one thing to condemn the law, as Manichaeus did; it is another to prefer the Gospel to the law, for this is in accordance with apostolic teaching.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:582
verses.text: In the law the servants of the Lord speak, in the Gospel the Lord Himself; in the former are the promises, in the latter their fulfilment; there are the beginnings, here is perfection; in the law the foundations of works are laid; in the Gospel the edifice is crowned with the top-stone of faith and grace.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:583
verses.text: I have mentioned this to show the character of the teaching given by our distinguished professor.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:584
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:585
verses.text: The hundredth heading runs thus: "A man can be without sin, and easily keep the commandments of God if he chooses," as to which enough has already been said.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:586
verses.text: And although he professes to imitate, or rather complete the work of the blessed martyr Cyprian in the treatise which the latter wrote toQuirinus, he does not perceive that he has said just the opposite in the work under discussion.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:587
verses.text: Cyprian, in the fifty-fourth heading of the third book, lays it down that no one is free from stain and without sin, and he immediately gives proofs, among them the passage in Job, "Who is cleansed from uncleanness? Not he who has lived but one day upon the earth".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:588
verses.text: And in the fifty-first Psalm, "Behold I was shapen in iniquity, and in sin did my mother conceive me".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:589
verses.text: And in the Epistle of John, "If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:590
verses.text: You, on the other hand, maintain that "A man can be without sin," and that you may give your words the semblance of truth, you immediately add, "And easily keep the commandments of God, if he chooses," and yet they have been seldom or never kept by any one.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:591
verses.text: Now, if they were easy, they ought to have been kept by all.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:592
verses.text: But if, to concede you a point, at rare intervals some one may be found able to keep them, it is clear that what is rare is difficult.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:593
verses.text: And by way of supplementing this and displaying the greatness of your own virtues (we are to believe, forsooth, that you bring forth the sentiment out of the treasure of a good conscience), you have a heading to the effect that: "We ought not to commit even light offences".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:594
verses.text: And for fear some one might think you had not explained in the work the meaning of light, you add that, "We must not even think an evil thought," forgetting the words, "Who understands his offences? Clear thou me from hidden faults, and keep back thy servant from presumptuous sins, O Lord".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:595
verses.text: You should have known that the Church admits even failures through ignorance and sins of mere thought to be offences; so much so that she bids sacrifices be offered for errors, and the high priest who makes intercession for the whole people previously offers victims for himself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:596
verses.text: Now, if he were not himself righteous, he would never be commanded to offer for others.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:597
verses.text: Nor, again, would he offer for himself if he were free from sins of ignorance.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:598
verses.text: If I were to attempt to show that error and ignorance is sin, I must roam at large over the wide fields of Scripture.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:599
Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:600
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:601
verses.text: Pray have you not read that"He who looks upon a woman to lust after her hath committed adultery with her already in his heart?" It seems that not only are the look and the allurements to vice reckoned as sin, but whatever it be to which we give assent.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:602
verses.text: For either we can avoid an evil thought, and consequently may be free from sin; or, if we cannot avoid it, that is not reckoned as sin which cannot be avoided.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:603
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:604
verses.text: Your argument is ingenious, but you do not see that it goes against Holy Scripture, which declares that even ignorance is not without sin.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:605
verses.text: Hence it was that Job offered sacrifices for his sons, lest, perchance, they had unwittingly sinned in thought.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:606
verses.text: And if, when one is cutting wood, the axe-head flies from the handle and kills a man, the owner iscommanded to go to one of the cities of refuge and stay there until the high priest dies; that is to say, until he is redeemed by the Saviour's blood, either in the baptistery, or in penitence which is a copy of the grace of baptism, through the ineffable mercy of the Saviour, who would not have any one perish, nor delights in the death of sinners, but would rather that they should be converted and live.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:607
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:608
verses.text: It is surely strange justice to hold me guilty of a sin of error of which my conscience does not accuse itself.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:609
verses.text: I am not aware that I have sinned, and am I to pay the penalty for an offence of which I am ignorant? What more can I do, if I sin voluntarily?  A.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:610
verses.text: Do you expect me to explain the purposes and plans of God? The Book of Wisdom gives an answer to your foolish question:"Look not into things above thee, and search not things too mighty for thee".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:611
verses.text: And elsewhere, "Make not thyself overwise, and argue not more than is fitting".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:612
verses.text: And in the same place, "In wisdom and simplicity of heart seek God".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:613
verses.text: You will perhaps deny the authority of this book; listen then to the Apostle blowing the Gospel trumpet:"O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past tracing out! For who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been His counsellor?" Your questions are such as he elsewhere describes:"But foolish and ignorant questioning avoid, knowing that they gender strifes".

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:614
verses.text: And in Ecclesiastes (a book concerning which there can be no doubt) we read,"I said, I will be wise, but it was far from me.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:615
verses.text: That which is exceeding deep, who can find it out?" You ask me to tell you why the potter makes one vessel to honour, another to dishonour, and will not be satisfied with Paul, who replies on behalf of his Lord,"O man, who art thou that repliest against God?"  The remainder of this book is occupied by a series of quotations from the Old Testament, designed to show that it is not only the outer and conscious act which is reckoned sinful, but the opposition to the Divine will, which is often implicit and half-conscious.

verses.name: Jerome: Against the Pelagians Book I 1:616
verses.text: Occasionally, also, the speaker shows how the texts quoted enforce the argument which he has before used, that men may be spoken of as righteous in a general sense, yet by no means free from sins of thought or desire, if not of act.
